awd_titl_txt: RoL: EAGER: DESYN-C3: Moving information across synthetic membranes via engineered sensors
awd_abstract_narration:
Pseudocell engineering is the design and synthesis of structures that mimic real cell functions.  These structures can be useful for biotechnological applications or to advance our understanding of cellular processes. Cell membranes often isolate intracellular reactions from the extracellular environment. To enable pseudocells to control when and how reactions take place requires technologies to sense the external environment without requiring a flow of materials. Living cells accomplish this goal using sensor proteins installed within the cell's outer membrane. This project will coordinately design proteins and membranes to perform similar sensory and signaling roles. This project will also train students and will enhance ongoing outreach activities.  A diverse STEM workforce will be developed by engaging undergraduates in research through Northwestern University's iGEM team and its synthetic biology-focused REU, SynBREU.

This project will develop strategies for embedding protein sensors in synthetic membranes. This will help uncover relationships between membrane and protein design features. Achieving productive biosensor performance will be integral to evaluating the design process. The approach taken is based on preliminary data that demonstrates the feasibility of using cell-free expression systems to insert a functional channel protein (MscL) into vesicle membranes. This will be combined with the Modular Extracellular Sensing Architecture (MESA) developed by the co-PI to generate novel biosensors that are orthogonal to native systems. Ligand binding induces dimerization of MESA chains triggering an internal response without transmembrane transport of material. This approach will be evaluated using rapamycin as the external signal and split green fluorescent protein as the internal reporter. If successful, the approach will be extended to using vascular endothelial growth factor as the signal molecule and split Nano-Luciferase as the reporter.  If successful, this project will benefit society by ultimately enabling the use of pseudocell technology for improved environmental stewardship, and for improved patient care and treatment. The technologies to be developed here will benefit the biotechnology and pharmaceutical industries by enabling the development of new classes of therapeutic and diagnostic products.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Cells sense environmental signals (small molecules, force, light) via their cellular membranes and embedded membrane proteins. Together, these structures detect and transmit signals to the cell interior. While certain molecules are directly transported across the cell membrane, a variety of other signals remain on the cell exterior and signal transduction is accomplished by the interaction of membrane proteins with proteins inside the cell. Recreating this phenomena in systems designed to mimic the biological cell will not only help uncover biological principles guiding this process in cells, but also lead to a variety of technological applications including the design of advanced biosensors and therapeutic nanoparticles that can sense and respond to environmental cues.

 

The goal of this project was to develop strategies for embedding proteins in synthetic membranes to design new types of biosensors. Towards this end, we have successfully demonstrated that a series of membrane proteins can be synthesized and integrated into lipid nanoparticle membranes to assemble a series of biological sensors. We uncovered design rules for controlling protein orientation and position once in the membrane. In addition, we were successful in designing a complete signal transduction cascade in which an environmental signal interacted with a membrane protein in order to trigger the production of a protein inside a vesicle. To accomplish this, we used a combination of cell-free protein expression methods, lipid nanoparticle assembly methods, and optical assays to detect protein production. Remarkably, we find our sensor is specific to an environmental signal depending on the membrane protein we use, mimicking the selectivity and specificity of natural membrane proteins.  A second outcome of our project was the design of therapeutic vesicles derived from biological cells or synthetic vesicles. These therapeutic vesicles demonstrated functions such as protection from viral infection and cytotoxicity to a model cancer cell line.

 

The broader impacts of this grant focused on expanding research experiences for several undergraduate students. We worked with a Research Experience for Undergraduate Program, led by Northwester’s Center of Synthetic Biology, to provide research experiences to students who have been underrepresented in STEM disciplines. In addition, we have trained several graduate students in the design of synthetic and cell-derived vesicles. The project has resulted in broad knowledge dissemination through 6 journal publications, 6 conference presentations to date, and training opportunities to 1 postdoctoral researcher, 6 graduate researchers, and several undergraduate students.

 


Last Modified: 03/31/2022
Modified by: Neha Kamat
